introduction:
Introduction
Cerebral palsy (CP) is a neurological disease characterized by non-progressive movement and posture disorders (Rosenbaum et al. 2007). In individuals with hemiplegic CP (HCP), the lesions lead to contralateral motor deficits. Individuals with HCP employ compensatory movement patterns when grasping objects with the affected hand, e.g., the step-by-step strategy, in which they plan the sequence of an action one by one rather than anticipating and planning the entire sequence of the upcoming action (Mutsaarts et al. 2005; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Trombly 1992, 1993). These specific movement patterns are also apparent in the unaffected hand, increasing the number of sub-movements (Hung and Meredith 2014; Rich et al. 2017; Souto et al. 2021).
Various behavioral studies indicated that specific motor difficulties in HCP patients are associated with deficits in motor planning (Duff and Gordon 2003; Mutsaarts et al. 2006; Steenbergen and Gordon 2006; Steenbergen et al. 2007, 2013). Electrophysiological studies suggest that motor execution deficits in these patients result from abnormal neural activities in the preparation phase before the onset of the movement (Van Elk et al. 2010a, b; Kurz et al. 2014). Maladaptive muscle activation patterns, e.g., spasticity and weakness, appear when the timing process is impaired (Sanger et al. 2010). Event-related potentials (ERPs) allow assessing the precise temporal resolution and measuring the time scales of the motor planning process, i.e., an area omitted in fMRI studies. A deeper understanding of the nature of higher-level problems (i.e., motor planning deficits) is necessary for successful therapeutic intervention.
Two regulatory systems govern human actions. The habitual system chooses actions based on the requirements of the current task. In comparison, the goal-directed system anticipates the conclusion of upcoming actions and selects actions accordingly (Daw et al. 2005; de Wit and Dickinson 2009; Dolan and Dayan 2013; Morris et al. 2016). Computational evidence demonstrated that the goal-directed system achieves the best possible outcome at the expense of energy and time; however, habitual action selection is faster and easier, but it is incapable of changing in light of environmental goals (Hardwick et al. 2018). The goal-directed system programs the motor plans and develops the action strategies by considering the future demands of the task and the environment (Johnson-Frey et al. 2004; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Mutsaarts et al. 2005, 2006). Motor planning, in general, refers to all cognitive and motor processes that occur during the preparation phase of a movement's reaction time. Wong et al. (2014) propose a more limited definition of motor planning as three "how" processes that work in concert to configure the movement to achieve the motor goal, namely action selection, abstract kinematics, and movement specification. These processes can occur almost instantly, necessitating using a technique with a high temporal resolution to capture the time course of each. Additionally, it has been demonstrated that people prefer to complete tasks in comfortable positions, even if they are forced to begin in uncomfortable positions. This effect is referred to as "end-state comfort," and it serves as the foundation for motor planning assessments (Rosenbaum et al. 1990, 2001).
Several studies supporting the left-hemispheric dominance hypothesis for motor planning have extensively focused on right-handed participants (Schluter et al. 1998, 2001; Haaland et al. 2004). This is a significant limitation that might lead to an apparent bias. In fact, the observed results may be the result of practice and experience with the right hand, rather than a generic left-hemisphere specialization for motor planning. A few studies on motor control in left-handed individuals have produced mixed results. For example, Janssen et al. (2009, 2011) investigated the motor planning process in the right and left-handed participants using a bimanual grasping task. The participants were instructed to grasp CD cases and put them in CD boxes with a specific orientation. The study found that the end-state comfort effect was only observed for the right hand in both groups, confirming the left-hemispheric dominance hypothesis for motor planning.
In contrast, Hughes et al. (2011) observed no difference in motor planning between left and right-handed individuals, showing that the initial grasp postures were similar for both dominant and non-dominant hands. Moreover, Sadeghi et al. (2021) investigated the hemispheric distribution of motor planning by comparing right and left-handed participants in an action selection task. The participants were instructed to perform the task with their dominant hands (corresponding to the dominant hemisphere). The results revealed no significant difference between the groups regarding movement-related measures (i.e., planning time, grasping time, and releasing time), and both right and left-handed participants used the same planning pattern for the initial grip selection.
Another body of research on patients with unilateral brain damage has produced contradictory evidence favoring the hemispheric distribution of motor planning. Some evidence supports the left-hemisphere dominance for motor planning, claiming that patients with left brain damage suffer from more severe motor planning deficits than patients with right brain damage (Haaland and Harrington 1996; Vingerhoets 2008; Steenbergen et al. 2004Craje et al. 2009). However, there is evidence that contradicts this hypothesis. Kirkpatrick et al. (2013) found no differences between children with right and left-HCP when performing an action planning task with the unaffected arm. Williams et al. (2011) showed that both right and left spastic hemiplegia children had similar response time and accuracy rates for the hand rotation task. Moreover, Dean et al. (2012) reported no differences between right and left hemiplegia from a stroke. As a result, it remains difficult to argue for a hemispheric distribution of motor planning; and it is unclear whether left-HCP or right-HCP patients experience more motor planning difficulties.
Brain reorganization is another critical point when discussing the hemispheric contribution of motor planning, particularly in the case of early brain damage. Cortical projections in children with unilateral cerebral palsy do not follow the typical contralateral pattern. The projections, instead, are reorganized into an ipsilateral or mixed pattern (Carr et al. 1993; Carneiro et al. 2020; Baranello et al. 2016; Williams et al. 2011). Furthermore, studies have shown that in patients with unilateral cerebral palsy, the hemisphere receiving afferent projections, including sensory information, may not correspond to the hemisphere sending efferent projections (Thickbroom et al. 2001). Weinstein et al. (2018) demonstrated the beneficial utilizing of multiple modalities (EEG, fMRI, TMS, EMG, and DTI) to assess hand function in patients with unilateral cerebral palsy, indicating multiple individual reorganization patterns.
Moreover, neurophysiological evidence established the complexity and variability of functional abilities in children with unilateral cerebral palsy. For instance, Ferre et al. (2020) used an atlas-based analysis to demonstrate that children with periventricular injuries performed significantly better on dexterity and bimanual hand function tests than children with middle cerebral artery injuries. Additionally, certain studies have indicated that the location and timing of the brain insult are unique to each child with unilateral cerebral palsy, resulting in individual differences despite a unitary diagnosis (Gupta et al. 2017; Dobson et al. 2011; Staudt et al. 2004).
In the present study, we investigated the hemispheric distribution of motor planning in two experiments. It is necessary to use a task sensitive to motor planning ability to evaluate motor planning ability. Thus, we selected an action selection task for the experiments. The action selection process is one of the crucial steps in motor planning, which requires selecting proper motor programs (Andersen and Cui 2009; Wong et al. 2014). For instance, when you choose to write with a pen, you must consider a different grip than when you wish to pass the pen on to a friend sitting beside you (Daprati and Sirigu 2006). Accordingly, we studied a specific handle-turning task in which participants would decide to rotate their hands and choose the proper grip for rotating the knob in different rotational angles and directions. Due to the electrophysiological nature of the study (i.e., ERP), it can provide appropriate measures for investigating cognitive processes underlying motor planning or "how" processes with temporal resolution. The ERP analysis focused on the P2 component, a positive ERP deflection over the frontocentral areas of the brain, and the neural correlate of action selection (Kühn et al., 2009; Smid et al., 1999). The P2 component, whether anterior P2 or P2a, peaked at approximately 200 ms after stimulus onset (Makeig et al. 1999; Potts 2004; Van Elk et al. 2010a, b). The P2 amplitude indicated a stimulus categorization mechanism, with higher amplitudes associated with increased processing and more complex stimulus characteristics (Van Elk et al., 2010a, b; Luck and Hillyard, 1994). Previous studies suggested that P2 amplitude could be associated with predicting an upcoming action (Nikolaev et al. 2008) and stimulus-response coupling (Gajewski and Falkenstein 2013; Gajewski et al. 2008). For example, Van Elk et al. (2010a, b) showed a weak action selection process in participants with unilateral cerebral palsy correlated with a substantial reduction in P2 amplitude. Experiment 1 focused on the left-hemisphere hypothesis for motor planning and compared left-HCP participants and right-handed control subjects. In Experiment 2, we compared left- and right-HCP participants to examine hemispheric control of action selection.
Experiment 1
We examined the hemispheric specialization of motor planning in the first experiment by comparing left-HCP and healthy right-handed control subjects. We instructed both groups to complete the task using only their right hand (the unaffected hand and the dominant hand in left-HCP and control subjects, respectively). Some studies support the left-hemisphere hypothesis for motor planning, demonstrating that deficits in motor planning are more pronounced when the left hemisphere is damaged (the right body side is affected) (Haaland and Harrington 1996; Vingerhoets 2008; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Craje et al. 2009). In line with this behavioral research, an electrophysiological study found that the overall P2 amplitude was approximately half that of control subjects in right-HCP participants (left-brain damage) (Van Elk et al. 2010a, b).
In contrast, some evidence refuted this hypothesis (Kirkpatrick et al. 2013; Williams et al. 2011; Dean et al. 2012). However, evidence regarding the complexity and variability of function in children with UCP is growing (Ferre et al. 2020; Weinstein et al. 2018; Gupta et al. 2017; Dobson et al. 2011; Staudt et al. 2004). Thus, given the brain reorganization, complexity, and heterogeneity of children with UCP, it is challenging to conclude excessive motor planning deficits or a lack of motor planning deficits in children with right hemiplegia as compensatory motor planning mechanisms and individual differences may be expected in the UCP group. Thus, no substantial evidence exists for hemispheric dominance in motor planning. The primary objective of the first experiment was to compare left-HCP and healthy right-handed control subjects' motor planning ability during a specific action selection task. We specifically examined the possibility of significant differences between the two groups in terms of P2 amplitude, movement-related measures, and initial grip selection planning patterns. Additionally, the effects of task complexity were examined on both the behavioral and neural levels.
methodology:
Methods (1)
Participants
The study included 12 participants diagnosed with left hemiplegic cerebral palsy (5 females, mean age = 25.7 years, SD = 3.36 years) and 14 neurologically healthy right-handed participants (9 females, mean age = 27.5 years, SD = 2.34 years) (see Table 1). Prior to the experiment, we assessed the ability of left-HCP and control and right-HCP subjects to deduce relationships using Raven's Progressive Matrices (the Standard version). Tables 2 and 3 show the mean ± standard deviation and t-test results for these three groups. Participants with HCP were recruited through outpatient rehabilitation centers voluntarily. They all possessed the necessary sitting balance and cognitive abilities to complete the task. Gross and fine manual skills were examined using the Box and Blocks test (gross dexterity, Mathiowetz et al. 1985) and the Purdue Pegboard test (fine dexterity, Tiffin 1985) for both affected and unaffected hands. We calculated a ratio for the severity of the affected hand's paresis and divided the affected hand's score by the unaffected hand's score. To this end, a score near 1 indicates mild paresis, with comparable hand function in both hands, whereas a score near 0 indicates severe paresis, with a significant difference in hand function between the impaired and unimpaired hand. The control group consisted of university students who agreed to participate in the study for a fee. All control participants were right-handed, as assessed by the four-item version of the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (scores [greater than or equal to] 61 indicate right-handedness and scores [less than or equal to] 61 indicate left-handedness) (Veale 2014). Experimental setup
The experimental setup consisted of a custom-made wedge (width: 40 cm) with a 45 Í¦ slope relative to the horizontal surface and a hexagonal plastic knob (width: 11 cm, depth: 6 cm) attached to the center of the wedge (Fig. 1A). The apparatus was placed on a table, and the participants were instructed to sit comfortably on a chair behind the apparatus and adjust their position to reach a suitable posture for performing the task. The hexagonal knob could fluidly rotate around the vertical axis. A touch sensor on each of the six sides of the knob recorded the maximum touch surface to detect the initial grip patterns. Subjects were required to grasp the hexagon with their thumb and fingers placed on opposite sides of it. As a result, they touched only two opposite sides of the hexagonal knob, and a sensor detected the position of the fingers in front of the thumb (the surface with the maximum touch).Fig. 1
A The experimental setup for motor planning assessment adapted from Mutsaart (2006). B The six grip patterns with the right hand (Grip 1-5, described in more details in Part C; Grip 4 was biomechanically impossible for all the participants). C Diagram indicating six possible locations of the four fingers in front of the thumb detected by the touch sensor, which is called Grip 1, Grip 2, and so on. D The schematic course of a trial of the task: holding the button, turning on the LEDs, releasing the button, grasping the hexagon, and finally releasing the hexagon and going back to the starting position
Subjects could grasp the hexagonal knob using five different grip types (i.e., Grip 1, Grip 2, Grip 3, Grip 5, and Grip 6). Grip 4 was biomechanically impossible for all the participants (see Fig. 1B, C). An arrow (width: 0.5 cm, length: 15 cm) was inserted on each of the knobs' six sides. Six LEDs were placed at 0 Í¦, 60 Í¦, 120 Í¦, 180 Í¦, 240 Í¦, and 300 Í¦ of the wedge. There was a start button in front of the wedge to allow the subjects to start the grasping movements. A PC running the presentation software (the motor planning system, TIWAN Technology Development Co.) controlled both the start button and the portable wedge to turn on the LEDs, record the movement-related measures, and detect the directions rotation angles. The movement-related measures included the planning time (i.e., the time in which the subject released the start button), the grasping time (i.e., the time between releasing the start button and grasping the knob), and the release time (i.e., the time between grasping and rotating the hexagonal knob). Different triggers corresponding to various task conditions were used to identify the events over the EEG signals and saved for the ERP analysis.
Experimental procedure
Before the experiment, the participants were informed to place one hand on the start button. HCP subjects performed our task with their unaffected hand to reduce the impact of biomechanical abnormalities such as spasticity, muscle tightness, and contracture, which was consistent with previous research involving participants with unilateral brain damage (Mutsaarts et al. 2005; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Van Elk et al. 2010a, b; Kirkpatrick et al. 2013). After choosing the most suitable planning pattern, participants were asked to release the start button, grasp the hexagon, and complete the rotation. Once the initial trial was completed, participants returned to the starting position and initiated the subsequent trial. The LED instructions included four different conditions, i.e., 60° and 180° clockwise (CW), and 60° and 180° counterclockwise (CCW). For example, if LEDs 1 and 2 were lit, the hexagon was required to be rotated 60° in the CW direction; however, if LEDs 1, 2, 3, and 4 were lit, the hexagon was required to be rotated 180° in the CW direction. Participants were instructed to release the start button as soon as they determined which grip to grab. Then, they would grab the hexagonal knob and complete the rotation in the pre-cued directions and rotational angles. Participants were free to select one of five possible grips. Each time the initial rotation was carried out, the hand returned to the start button to initiate the subsequent trial. The task consisted of 120 trials (2 directions x 2 rotation angles x 30 repetitions) sorted in random order.
The subjects had to perform the experiment as quickly as possible. At the beginning of the task, subjects were instructed to place their hand over the hexagonal knob and determine the most comfortable grip pattern. They all stated that Grip 1 (the one without a rotation) was the most comfortable. Before starting the main experiment, the subjects practiced a few trials to ensure the task was fully understood.
Behavioral data analysis
The behavioral data analysis focused on planning times, grasping times, releasing times, and initial grip selection planning patterns. The planning time was the time between turning on the LEDs and releasing the start button. The grasping time was the time between releasing the start button and grasping the hexagonal knob. The releasing time was the time between grasping the knob and releasing it after rotation (see Fig. 1D). The outlier data were omitted from the analysis's subsequent steps. The initial grips were coded by the touch sensor according to the location of the fingers in front of the thumb (see Fig. 1C).
To analyze the initial grip selections, three planning patterns were identified: no-planning pattern, effective-planning pattern, and wrong-planning pattern. Grip 1 (without a rotation grip) was defined as the no-planning pattern. Due to the dominance of the habitual system, simple methods are used without regard for future actions, which is a representation of the no-planning pattern (Hardwick et al. 2018). Therefore, the end-state comfort satisfaction is only provided for 60-degree rotations. In 180-degree rotations, subjects needed to rotate their hands in the opposite direction of the guided rotatory movements, i.e., they could not perform the task in comfortable postures. Therefore, Grip 5 and Grip 6 represented effective-planning patterns for rotatory movements in CW directions, while Grip 2 and Grip 3 represented effective-planning patterns for rotatory movements in CCW directions. The pattern of effective planning exemplified the use of a goal-directed system that predicts an action's future requirements (de Wit and Dickinson 2009). If subjects rotated their hands in the same direction at the start of rotatory movements, they would be unable to complete the task, or their hands would be left in an awkward position. To this end, Grips 2 and 3 were defined as wrong-planning patterns for rotatory movements in CW directions, while Grips 5 and 6 were defined as wrong-planning patterns for rotatory movements in CCW directions.
EEG recording and analysis
We recorded electroencephalogram (EEG; [mu]V) signals using a 32-channel amplifier (ANT Neuro, Enschede, Netherlands). Electrode array on Waveguard cap (ANT Neuro, Enschede, Netherlands) was based on the 10-20 system arrangement. All electrodes were referenced to the average of the left and right mastoids. To monitor both vertical and horizontal eye movements, we recorded the electrooculogram (EOG) signals using two electrodes placed below and adjacent to the left eye. The sampling rate of the amplifier was 625 Hz. The impedance of each electrode was kept below 10 k Ohm. An independent component analysis (ICA) procedure was used to remove ocular and movement artifacts (Delorme and Makeig 2004). Following ICA, a specialist excluded trials with movement artifacts from analysis based on a thorough visual examination of the raw data. For the ERP analysis, we used a 0.5 to 30 Hz two-pass finite impulse-response band pass filter (order: 3 cycles of the low-frequency cutoff) to filter the data.
The ERP analysis was performed during the planning time interval (the time between LEDs' cues and the release of the start button). ERPs were computed relative to the LEDs' cue from - 200 to 500 ms using the baseline time window of - 200 to 0 ms. Statistical analyses were focused on the amplitude of the P2 wave as the average of the amplitude from 180 to 220 ms post-stimulus onset. The average P2 amplitude was calculated on Fz and Cz electrodes. The averages of artifact-free trials were 114.83 ± 5.73 and 109.78 ± 8.47 in the left-HCP and control group, respectively [t (24) = 1.74, P = 0.09].
Methods (2)
Participants
For the second experiment, 12 participants with left-HCP (5 females, mean age = 25.75 years, SD = 3.36 years) and nine with right-HCP (3 females, mean age = 24.66 years, SD = 5.87 years) volunteered to participate. As with Experiment 1, participants with right-HCP were referred to the second experiment by outpatient rehabilitation centers. Moreover, they all signed the consent form before the experiment. The criteria for selecting participants for Experiment 2 were the same as those of Experiment 1, listed in Table 2.
EEG recording and analysis
Similar to Experiment 1, the P2 amplitude was analyzed offline as the average amplitude from 180 to 220 ms after stimulus onset; however, this time, at three regions of interest (ROI), i.e., the left fronto-central ROI (F3, FC1, and C3), the fronto-central ROI (Fz and Cz), and the right fronto-central ROI (F4, FC2, and C4). ERPs were tested for statistical significance using a 2 x 2 x 3 x 2 general linear model (GLM) with 'rotation' (60° vs. 180°) and 'direction' (CCW vs. CW directions) and region (left-ROI, central-ROI, and right-ROI) as within-subject variables and 'group' (left-HCP subjects vs. control subjects) as the between-subjects factor. The left region was evaluated because it appears that the left hemisphere is critical for motor planning. On the other hand, the right region was assessed because some studies have confirmed the right hemisphere's role in mental rotation (Serrien et al. 2006). Furthermore, we evaluated the central region (i.e., the visual processing pathway) because Van Elk et al. (2010a, b) hypothesize that this area is where action selection occurs. Finally, because we assessed the left-hemisphere dominance hypothesis for motor planning to the distributed theory, which postulates bilateral motor planning, we evaluated three regions of interest.
The averages of artifact-free trials were 114.83 ± 5.73 and 114 ± 6.30 in the left- and right-HCP group, respectively [t (19) = - 0.31, P = 0.75].

Results (1)
Behavioral data
The behavioral data analysis focused on planning, grasping, and releasing times. A 2 x 2 x 2 repeated measures general linear model (GLM) was used with 'direction' (counterclockwise vs. clockwise) and 'rotation angle' (60° vs. 180°) as within-subject variables and 'group' (left-HCP subjects vs. control subjects) as the between-subjects factor. The planning time analyses showed a main effect for 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 22.55, P < 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.48], indicating that increased rotation angles were associated with increased planning times (see Fig. 2A). There was a main effect for 'direction' [F (1, 24) = 6.11, P = 0.021, É³ 2 = 0.2], suggesting that planning times were slower for CW directions compared to CCW directions. An interaction effect was found for 'direction' x 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 8.22, P = 0.008, É³ 2 = 0.25]. Two paired t -tests were performed separately between the directions, in which the planning time was significantly higher at 180° CW than 180° CCW [t (25) = 2.96, P = 0.007], whereas such a significant difference was not observed in 60° rotations [t (25) = - 0.61, P = 0.54]. Moreover, an interaction between 'direction' x 'rotation' x 'group' was found [F (1, 24) = 5.57, P = 0.027, É³ 2 = 0.18].Fig. 2
Behavioral results of the first experiment. Graphs representing planning times (A ), grasping times (B ), releasing times (C ), the distribution of the planning patterns used by left-HCP subjects (black bars) and control subjects (white bars) (D ), the distribution of the planning patterns in two different directions CW (black bars) and CCW (white bars) (E ) and the distribution of the planning patterns in two different rotation angles 60° (black bars) and 180° (white bars) (F ). Error bars indicate ± 1 SE
We performed paired t -tests separately for each group, indicating that left-HCP subjects had significantly higher planning time in 180° CW than CCW [t (11) = 2.77, P = 0.018]; however, for the rotation angles of 60°, this difference was not significant [t (11) = - 0.94, P = 0.36]. There was no significant difference in planning time between 60° and 180° in CCW and CW direction in control subjects. A main effect was found for 'group' [F (1, 24) = 11.25, P = 0.003, É³ 2 = 0.31], indicating slower planning times for left-HCP subjects (average planning time = 693.06 ms, SE = 48.23 ms) compared to the control group (average planning time = 472.52 ms, SE = 44.65 ms). On the other hand, the control group acted faster.
The analysis of grasping times also showed a significant main effect for 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 28.93, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.54], indicating that grasping times were slower for greater angle rotations (e.g., 180°) compared to smaller rotation angles (e.g., 60°) (see Fig. 2B). A main effect for 'direction' [F (1, 24) = 6.08, P = 0.021, É³ 2 = 0.2] indicated that grasping times were slower for CW directions (i.e., LEDs instruction: 1, 2, 3, and 4) than CCW directions (i.e., LEDs instruction: 1, 6, 5, and 4). As was the case with planning time, an interaction effect was observed between 'direction' and 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 4.4, P = 0.04, É³ 2 = 0.15]. Two paired t -tests confirmed the results, indicating the grasping time was significantly higher at 180° CW than 180° CCW [t (25) = 2.90, P = 0.008]; however, there was no significant difference for grasping time in 60° CCW than CW direction [t (25) = 0.18, P = 0.85]. There was no significant effect for 'group' [F (1, 24) = 3.28, P = 0.08, É³ 2 = 0.12].
As expected, the analysis of releasing times revealed a main effect for 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 79.23, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.76], indicating slower releasing times for greater angle rotations (e.g., 180°) compared to smaller angle rotations (e.g., 60°) (see Fig. 2C). There was no main effect for 'direction' [F (1, 24) = 0.36, P = 0.55, É³ 2 = 0.01], and no main effect was observed for 'group' [F (1, 24) = 0.02, P = 0.88, É³ 2 = 0.001].
The analysis of planning patterns for the initial grip selection was performed using a 2 x 2 x 3 x 2 repeated measures general linear model (GLM) with 'direction' (counterclockwise vs. clockwise), 'rotation angle' (60° vs. 180°), and 'planning pattern' (no-planning pattern vs. effective-planning pattern vs. wrong-planning pattern) as within-subject variables and 'group' (left-HCP subjects vs. control subjects) as the between-subjects factor. In analyzing planning patterns for the initial grip selection, the main effect was found for 'planning pattern' [F (2, 48) = 40.12, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.62], indicating that the effective-planning pattern was used more often than the two other patterns (i.e., no-planning pattern and wrong-planning pattern).
A significant interaction was found between 'planning pattern' x 'group' [F (2, 48) = 5.06, P = 0.01, É³ 2 = 0.17]. Three independent t -tests were performed separately between grip patterns. Regarding the no-planning pattern, the difference between the two groups was not significant [t (24) = - 1.13, P = 0.26], indicating both groups selected the no-planning pattern equally. However, there was a significant difference between groups in terms of the effective-planning pattern [t (24) = 2.89, P = 0.008], implying that the control group grasped the hexagon with better motor planning (average number of selection of the effective-planning pattern per category = 72.2, SD = 5.2) compared to left-HCP subjects (average number of selection of the effective-planning pattern per category = 49.93, SD = 5.6). In addition, a significant difference was found between the two groups in terms of the wrong-planning pattern [t (24) = - 3.21, P = 0.004], demonstrating that the left-HCP subjects often selected an inappropriate grip (average number of selection of the wrong-planning pattern per category = 12.91, SD = 2.8) compared to the control group (average number of selection of the wrong-planning pattern per category = 0.35, SD = 2.6).
There was an interaction between 'planning pattern' x 'direction' [F (2, 48) = 18.69, P < 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.43], indicating that the effective-planning patterns were more often used for CCW directions. Paired t -tests confirmed these results [t (25) = - 4.92, P < 0.001]. Moreover, there was an interaction effect between 'planning pattern' x 'rotation' [F (2, 48) = 27.86, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.53], indicating that the effective-planning patterns were more often used for 180° rotations, whereas subjects preferred the no-planning patterns for 60° rotations. Paired t -tests analysis showed that there were significant differences between these two rotation angles in the no-planning pattern [t (25) = 4.55, P Ë 0.001] and the effective-planning pattern [t (25) = - 5.08, P Ë 0.001]; however, there was no significant difference between them in the wrong-planning pattern [t (25) = 0.72, P = 0.47]. These results are depicted in Fig. 2D.
Event-related potentials (ERPs)
ERPs were tested for statistical significance using a 2 x 2 x 2 general linear model (GLM) with 'rotation' (60° vs. 180°) and 'direction' (CCW vs. CW directions) as within-subject variables and 'group' (left-HCP subjects vs. control subjects) as the between-subjects factor. Figure 3 depicts the ERPs for left-HCP and control subjects during the motor planning task. A main effect for 'group' was observed [F (1, 24) = 5.13, P = 0.03, É³ 2 = 0.17]. As indicated in Fig. 3A, participants in the left-HCP group showed a lower P2 amplitude (average amplitude = 2.46 [mu]V, SE = 0.41 [mu]V) compared to the healthy right-handed control subjects (average amplitude = 3.74 [mu]V, SE = 0.38 [mu]V). There was a main effect for 'rotation' [F (1, 24) = 28.79, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.54], indicating that an increase in the P2 amplitude was associated with an increase in the rotation angle (Fig. 3B). A main effect was found for 'direction' [F (1, 24) = 7.01, P = 0.014, É³ 2 = 0.22], showing a higher P2 amplitude for CW directions compared to CCW directions (Fig. 3C).Fig. 3

Results (2)
Behavioral data
The second experiment's behavioral data were analyzed statistically in the same way as Experiment 1. A 2 x 2 x 2 repeated measures general linear model (GLM) was used with 'direction' (counterclockwise vs. clockwise) and 'rotation angle' (60° vs. 180°) as within-subject variables and 'group' (right-HCP vs. left-HCP subjects) as the between-subjects factor. There was a significant main effect for 'rotation' on planning time [F (1, 19) = 21.34, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.52], indicating that the planning time increased with greater rotation angles (see Fig. 4A). No main effect was observed for 'direction' [F (1, 19) = 2.34, P = 0.14, É³ 2 = 0.11]. There was an interaction effect for 'direction' x 'group' [F (1, 19) = 14.36, P = 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.43]. The paired t -test revealed that the right-HCP group was significantly slower in CCW directions than in CW directions [t (8) = 3.32, P = 0.01]. However, such a significant difference was not observed in the left-HCP group [t (11) = - 1.8, P = 0.09] (see Fig. 5). An interaction between 'direction' x 'rotation' x 'group' [F (1, 19) = 7.5, P = 0.01, É³ 2 = 0.28] indicated that the right-HCP group was faster at 180° CW than CCW [t (8) = - 3.22, P = 0.01]; however, for the rotation angles of 60°, this difference was not significant [t (8) = - 1.97, P = 0.08]. The left-HCP group was faster in CCW directions, but only for the 180° rotation [t (11) = 2.77, P = 0.01]. No effect was found for 'group' [F (1, 19) = 0.001, P = 0.98, É³ 2 = 0.001].Fig. 4

Analyzing grasping times indicated a significant main effect for 'rotation' [F (1, 19) = 27.68, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.59], indicating longer grasping times for greater rotation angles (e.g., 180°) compared to smaller rotation angles (e.g., 60°) (see Fig. 4B). No main effect was found for 'direction' [F (1, 19) = 2.44, P = 0.13, É³ 2 = 0.11]. There was an interaction effect for 'direction' x 'group' [F (1, 19) = 6.3, P = 0.02, É³ 2 = 0.24]. As was the case for the planning time, we performed two paired t-tests, showing that the right-HCP group was slower in CCW directions than in CW directions [t (8) = - 2.2, P = 0.05]. On the other hand, the left-HCP group acted faster in CCW directions; however, their action was not significant [t (11) = 0.9, P = 0.38] (see Fig. 5). Analyzing planning patterns for the initial grip selection was performed using a 2 x 2 x 3 x 2 repeated measures general linear model (GLM) with 'direction' (counterclockwise vs. clockwise), 'rotation angle' (60° vs. 180°), and 'planning pattern' (no-planning pattern vs. effective-planning pattern vs. wrong-planning pattern) as within-subject variables and 'group' (right-HCP vs. left-HCP subjects) as the between-subjects factor. The analysis of planning patterns for the initial grip selection showed a main effect for 'planning pattern' [F (2, 38) = 16.72, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.46], suggesting that the effective-planning pattern was more applicable than the two other patterns. A significant interaction was found between 'planning pattern' x 'direction' x 'group' [F (2, 38) = 11.75, P Ë 0.001, É³ 2 = 0.38], indicating that the left-HCP group had a significant difference between the directions in the effective-planning pattern [t (11) = - 3.35, P = 0.006] and the no-planning pattern [t (11) = 3.56, P = 0.004]. There was no significant difference between the directions in the wrong-planning pattern [t (11) = 1.36, P = 0.2]. However, the right-HCP group showed a significant difference between the directions in the effective-planning pattern [t (8) = 4.09, P = 0.003] and the wrong-planning pattern [t (8) = - 3.17, P = 0.01]. discussion:
Discussion (1)
The first experiment yielded three significant findings: First, left-HCP subjects were slower in planning times and chose the effective-planning pattern less frequently than the control group. Second, the P2 amplitude was smaller in left-HCP subjects than in healthy control subjects. Third, we discovered that left-HCP subjects and the right-handed control group had increased P2 amplitudes and movement-related times (e.g., planning times, grasping times, and releasing times) when planning complex actions, such as 180° rotations.
Experiment 2
In the second experiment, both left- and right-HCP subjects performed the same task with their unaffected hand as in Experiment 1 (the right-hand and the left-hand in left-HCP and right-HCP subjects, respectively). It should be noted that we used data from the first experiment on participants with left-HCP. The second experiment's primary objective was to compare the motor planning ability of left- and right-HCP subjects during the task. We specifically examined the possibility of significant differences between the two groups in terms of P2 amplitude, movement-related measures, and initial grip selection planning patterns. Additionally, the effects of task complexity were examined on both the behavioral and neural levels.
Discussion (2)
The second experiment yielded three significant findings: First, there was no evidence of a significant group effect in the movement-related measures (i.e., planning time, grasping time, and releasing time). Subjects with right and left HCP acted similarly and preferred medial direction. Second, there was a neural interaction between the ROI and the group, indicating a significant difference in the right region between the two groups. Third, there was a complexity effect at both the behavioral and neural levels, indicating that both left- and right-HCP subjects had increased P2 amplitudes and enhanced movement-related times (e.g., planning times, grasping times, and releasing times) when planning actions involving complex conditions, such as 180° rotations.
General discussion
The review of the literature revealed that several studies corroborated the hypothesis of left-hemispheric dominance in motor planning and motor imagery (e.g., Schluter et al. 1998, 2001; Johnson et al. 2001; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Crajé et al. 2009; Mutsaarts et al. 2007; Janssen et al. 2009, 2011), while several studies were contradicted this hypothesis (e.g., Kirkpatrick et al. 2013; Williams et al. 2011; Hughes et al. 2011; Dean et al. 2012; Steenbergen et al. 2007). Furthermore, neurophysiological evidence indicates that compensatory reorganization patterns following early brain damage result in individual differences among HCP patients (Carneiro et al. 2020; Ferre et al. 2020; Weinstein et al. 2018; Gupta et al. 2017; Baranello et al. 2016; Williams et al. 2011; Dobson et al. 2011; Staudt et al. 2004; Carr et al. 1993). This study aimed to determine whether motor planning was confined to one side of the brain (left side) or if both sides contributed. Therefore, we examined motor planning in left-HCP and healthy control subjects using an action selection task (Experiment 1) and left-HCP and right-HCP subjects using the same task (Experiment 2).
The first experiment revealed that subjects with left-HCP had slower planning times. Individuals with HCP have previously shown deficits in anticipatory action planning (Mutsaarts et al. 2005, 2006; Steenbergen et al. 2004; Craje et al. 2010). Additionally, it has been demonstrated that these patients must spend additional time preparing for sequential movements (Duff and Gordon 2003). Steenbergen et al. (2007) demonstrated that both the right and left hemiplegia groups were slower than the control group using a 'bar-handling' paradigm. The initial grip selection analysis revealed an interaction effect between the planning pattern and the group, indicating that left-HCP subjects chose less effective planning patterns than the control group. Motor planning with the unimpaired hand in HCP patients is task-dependent (Mutsaarts et al. 2006; Steenbergen et al. 2004). Mutsaarts et al. (2006) discovered that children with HCP can plan simple movements using their unimpaired hands.
Furthermore, in line with our findings, Steenbergen et al. (2004) discovered that participants demonstrated an end-state comfort preference for the unimpaired hand, but the magnitude of this effect was different. Moreover, there was a significant interaction between the planning pattern and the rotation angle, indicating that more effective patterns were used for 180° rotation angles. Individuals must use a goal-directed system when confronted with complex planning conditions (i.e., 180° rotations); otherwise, they will fail to achieve end-state comfort satisfaction (Rosenbaum et al. 1990). Additionally, there was a significant interaction between planning pattern and direction, indicating that subjects used more effective grip patterns when rotating the hexagon in CCW directions, considered medial rotations for both left-HCP participants and the control group. Kirkpatrick et al. (2013) also observed that when left-HCP children were preparing to perform the motor planning task, they preferred CCW rotations in grasping the knob. The P2 amplitude of left-HCP subjects was smaller at the neural level than that of healthy control subjects. This finding is consistent with Van Elk et al. (2010a, b), who discovered that the P2 amplitude of HCP subjects was approximately half that of control subjects.
At the behavioral level, a significant effect for rotation was observed, consistent with the notion that is increasing task complexity (i.e., increased rotation angles) necessitates spending more time processing and executing. In the behavioral section of their study, Van Elk et al. (2010a, b) showed that an increased rotation angle was associated with increased motor-related measures. Moreover, in the present study, we found that left-HCP participants and the control group had increased P2 amplitudes for the preparation phase of actions with complex conditions (e.g., 180° rotations). According to the complexity effect, previous research has demonstrated that the amplitude of the P2 component is modulated by the evaluation of the stimulus and the upcoming motor response (Kühn et al. 2009; Potts 2004). We also found a significant main effect for the direction at the behavioral level, indicating longer planning times (or grasping times) for CW directions (lateral rotation) than CCW directions (medial rotation).
Movements in the medial direction (i.e., when people move their hands toward the body's midline) have an advantage over movements in the lateral direction (i.e., when people move their hands away from the body's midline) because they can be planned and executed more easily and quickly (Parsons 1994, 1987). This phenomenon is called the medial-over-lateral advantage or MOLA (Funk and Brugger 2008), which has been demonstrated in mental rotation tasks (Parsons 1994, 1987; Funk and Brugger 2008) and motor planning paradigms (Kirkpatrick et al. 2013). In addition, we found an effect for the direction at the neural level, indicating larger P2 amplitudes for CW directions. There was an interaction between the direction and the rotation, showing that planning times (and grasping times) were more significant in CW directions for 180° rotations than 60° rotations. This finding can be explained by the notion that complex circumstances compel individuals to employ a goal-directed system and plan for future actions (Rosenbaum et al. 1990).
The second experiment showed no significant difference between the groups (i.e., right-HCP and left-HCP) at either behavioral or neural levels. We observed an interaction between direction and group at the behavioral level, indicating a MOLA effect in the right-HCP group, where they demonstrated faster planning (grasping) times in CW directions than CCW directions. Consistent with our findings, Kirkpatrick et al. (2013) observed no difference in movement times between two hemiplegic groups and demonstrated an interaction between direction and group, indicating a preference for movements into the body's midline, which is consistent with the MOLA. Furthermore, Williams et al. (2011) revealed that children with left and right spastic hemiplegia acted with the same response time and had similar accuracy rates on a motor imagery task. The interaction between the direction, the rotation, and the group indicated that left-HCP subjects acted faster in CCW directions, while the opposite is observed in participants with right-HCP; however, these preferences only appear for 180° rotations. Given that the MOLA effect is a characteristic of motor planning, it can be linked to the idea that complex tasks require people to use motor planning more effectively (Van Elk et al. 2010a, b).
Also, there was a significant interaction between the ROI and the group, with right-HCP subjects having larger P2 amplitudes in the right ROI (F4, C4, and FC2). However, the region was largely unaffected. Furthermore, previous research utilizing source-level analysis has demonstrated that the motor planning process may originate in more central structures (Van Elk et al. 2010a, b; Kurz et al. 2014). Thus, this finding may reflect an individual response in our right-HCP group and may be related to the multiple brain reorganization patterns observed in patients with CP (Carneiro et al. 2020; Ferre et al. 2020; Weinstein et al. 2018; Gupta et al. 2017; Dobson et al. 2011; Baranello et al. 2016; Staudt et al. 2004).
The present study found that right-HCP and left-HCP participants had increased P2 amplitudes and enhanced movement-related times (e.g., planning times, grasping times, and releasing times) for planning actions with complex conditions, e.g., 180° rotations compared to 60° rotations. Previous research has shown that P2 amplitude is associated with the anticipation of an upcoming action (Nikolaev et al. 2008) and the stimulus-response coupling; hence, complex tasks elicit larger P2 amplitudes than easy tasks (Gajewski et al. 2008; Gajewski and Falkenstein 2013).
Moreover, analyzing planning patterns for the initial grip selection indicated a significant interaction between the planning pattern, the direction, and the group. This interaction demonstrates that subjects with a right-HCP prefer more effective planning patterns in CW directions, whereas subjects with a left-HCP act oppositely. These findings corroborate those of Kirkpatrick et al. (2013), who found that participants with right-HCP preferred to grasp the knob in CW rather than CCW directions. In addition, there was another interaction between the planning pattern and the rotation, which indicated that the participants selected more effective-planning patterns for 180° rotations, while the no-planning pattern was selected for 60° rotations. This finding can be explained by the competition between the habitual and the goal-directed control systems. The habitual control system operates in routine and easy ways without regard for further action demands.
On the other hand, a goal-directed control system anticipates the entirety of the movement's action sequence prior to executing it (Rosenbaum et al. 1990; Johnson-Frey et al. 2004; Stöckel et al. 2012). For instance, individuals who face simple planning conditions (i.e., 60° rotations) can quickly solve them and achieve end-state comfort satisfaction using the habitual control system. However, when confronted with complex planning conditions (i.e., 180° rotations), the goal-directed system is the only one capable of achieving end-state comfort satisfaction. Therefore, individuals must use the goal-directed control system for 180° rotations (complex planning conditions) and immediately reverse their hands. Otherwise, they will be unable to complete the task successfully or will find themselves with their hands in an awkward position.
Overall, the findings indicate that left-HCP subjects exhibited motor planning deficits relative to the control group, which contradicts the left-hemisphere hypothesis. Moreover, we observed no difference in behavior or neural activity in experiment 2, indicating that left- and right-HCP subjects performed identically on the action selection task. The evidence does not support left-hemispheric dominance of motor planning (Kirkpatrick et al. 2013; Williams et al. 2011; Hughes et al. 2011; Dean et al. 2012; Steenbergen et al. 2007). Given that both sides of the body's motion programming are entirely dependent on one another, a distributed motor planning system across hemispheres is expected rather than a left-lateralized motor planning control system (Baraldi et al. 1999; Wang 2001; Guo et al. 2017). As previously demonstrated, hemispheric asymmetry is expected in lower-level processing, such that the contralateral hemisphere can partially segregate the execution of movements on each body side (Toga and Thompson 2003; Duboc et al. 2015; Wang et al. 2014).
Nevertheless, there is no certainty about higher-level processes such as motor planning (Hughes et al. 2011; Kirkpatrick et al. 2013). However, the rationale for the hemispheric distribution of motor planning in children born with congenital hemiplegic cerebral palsy remains unknown. Because brain damage occurs early in development in patients with HCP, compensatory reorganization patterns may result in individual differences in this population. Further research can be conducted to elucidate the hemispheric distribution of motor planning. These studies will require additional neurophysiological and clinical data and high-resolution ERP analysis (source analysis) to trace the spatial characteristics of the response that may change as a result of the pathology. Additionally, advanced imaging technologies (e.g., DTI) are required to correlate observed changes in cortical oscillations with the biomechanical deficiencies of CP patients.
conclusion:
Conclusion
The current study's first experimental results indicate that the control group outperformed the left-HCP subjects, contradicting the left-hemisphere hypothesis. According to this hypothesis, patients with right brain damage exhibit a disproportionately negative effect on motor planning abilities. In the second experiment, we observed no significant behavioral or neural differences between left- and right-HCP subjects, inconsistent with left-hemisphere dominance for motor planning. However, motor planning distribution remains a challenge in children with congenital HCP than healthy children or those with acquired hemiplegia.
Limitation
Our study has some limitations that should be addressed in subsequent research. The first was the participant's absence of imaging data to confirm the location of lesions in one or both hemispheres. Only a hand dexterity test was used to assess the severity of the affected hand paralysis. Also, due to the small window of recorded planning time, time-frequency analysis of neurophysiological components was not possible.

abstract:
Task-dependent changes in inhibition may explain why supraspinal excitability is higher during arm cycling than an intensity- and position-matched tonic contraction. The present study investigated whether interhemispheric inhibition (IHI) associated with biceps brachii activity was different during arm cycling, a locomotor output, compared to a tonic contraction. IHI was quantified using an ipsilateral silent period (iSP) evoked via transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) of the ipsilateral motor cortex. TMS was delivered at 120% resting motor threshold during the mid-elbow flexion phase of arm cycling (6 o'clock position, made relative to a clock face) and during a position- and intensity-matched tonic contraction. In total, 36 participants took part in the study. However, only 14 participants demonstrated IHI during arm cycling and 10 participants during tonic contraction. Of these participants, eight displayed clear iSPs during arm cycling and tonic contraction. The iSP duration was longer during arm cycling than tonic contraction (p < 0.05), while iSP EMG amplitude and area were not different between tasks (p > 05 for both comparisons). The main finding from this study is that IHI appears to be stronger during arm cycling than an intensity- and position-matched tonic contraction. This does not support previous findings of higher supraspinal excitability during arm cycling.

introduction:
Introduction
Arm cycling is a bilateral, multi-joint, rhythmic motor output that resembles other forms of locomotor outputs in humans, such as walking and running, and is frequently used as a model to examine the neural control of human locomotion (for review, see Zehr et al. 2016; Power et al. 2018). The basic pattern of arm cycling is partially generated by specialized groups of interneurones within the spinal cord known as central pattern generators (CPGs) (Grillner and Wallen 1985; Dietz 2002; Zehr et al. 2004) as is the case for locomotion in non-human animals (Brown and Sherrington 1911), though descending inputs from the motor cortex is of greater importance in humans (Christensen et al. 2001; Petersen et al. 2001; Barthelemy and Nielsen 2010; Barthelemy et al. 2011). Although much work has examined corticospinal and spinal excitability during locomotor output, a few studies have assessed the excitability of cortical circuitry (Sidhu et al. 2013, 2018; Alcock et al. 2019; Benson et al. 2021).
Cortical excitability is dependent on a balance between excitatory and inhibitory circuits acting within and/or between hemispheres (intra- and interhemispheric, respectively). Recent work has examined intrahemispheric circuits during locomotor output including short-interval intracortical inhibition (SICI) in the lower (Sidhu et al. 2013) and upper (Alcock et al. 2019) body and long-interval intracortical inhibition (LICI) (Sidhu et al. 2018) to the lower body. IHI is a logical circuit to assess given the bilateral nature of arm cycling, and that transcallosal interhemispheric connections between the primary motor cortices are proposed to play important roles in the control of unilateral and bilateral motor outputs (Ferbert et al. 1992; Carson 2005; Reis et al. 2008). However, the functional role of IHI during human motor output, in particular dynamic output, remains largely unknown (Carson 2005; Perez and Cohen 2009).
methodology:
In a recent study, we provided indirect evidence that IHI may be a mechanism contributing to the modulation of cortical excitability during arm cycling (Lockyer et al. 2020). We assessed corticospinal excitability to the ipsilateral biceps brachii during contralateral arm cycling when the ipsilateral arm was actively cycling, passively cycling, or at rest. Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS)-evoked motor-evoked potentials (MEPs) and transmastoid electrical stimulation (TMES)-evoked cervicomedullary motor-evoked potentials (CMEPs) were both highest when the ipsilateral arm was at rest. This led us to conclude that lower supraspinal excitability during bilateral arm cycling was possibly due to IHI between the active hemispheres, an effect that was reduced when the ipsilateral arm was not actively cycling. We subsequently assessed IHI using a TMS single pulse induced ipsilateral silent period (iSP) as opposed to the more commonly used paired-pulse TMS method. The iSP measures inhibition of volitional motor activity (TMS-induced decrease in ongoing electromyography amplitude, i.e., EMG) rather than a reduction in MEP amplitude. We showed that IHI was present to the biceps brachii during arm cycling (Benson et al. 2021), though we were unable to say with certainty whether the degree of IHI was specific to arm cycling (i.e., task-dependent), because we did not compare to a tonic contraction (Lockyer et al. 2021). Determining whether the amount of IHI is task-dependent is of importance and could shed light on our previous finding of higher supraspinal excitability during arm cycling compared to an intensity-matched tonic contraction (Forman et al. 2014).
The purpose of the present study was to determine whether the amount of IHI was different between arm cycling and an intensity- and position-matched tonic contraction. IHI was quantified during the aforementioned motor tasks using a single pulse paradigm as we have previously reported (Benson et al. 2021). Briefly, a single suprathreshold TMS pulse activates excitatory transcallosal axons that synapse onto inhibitory interneurones in the contralateral motor cortex, thus producing a brief suppression of descending excitation within the corticospinal pathway. This effect is visible as a suppression of the ongoing muscle activity as assessed via surface electromyography (EMG) referred to as the ipsilateral silent period (iSP) (Ferbert et al. 1992; Perez et al. 2014). The depth, area and duration of the iSP provide measures of IHI, also referred to as transcallosal inhibition (Perez et al. 2014). We hypothesized that IHI would be lower during arm cycling than a tonic contraction.
Methods
Ethical approval
Prior to data collection, all participants received verbal explanation of the experimental protocol. Once all questions were answered, written informed consent was obtained. This study was conducted in accordance with the Helsinki Declaration and all protocols were approved by the Interdisciplinary Committee on Ethics in Human Research at Memorial University of Newfoundland (ICEHR no. 20190339-HK). Additionally, the protocols were carried out in accordance with the Tri-Council Guidelines in Canada, with the potential risks being fully disclosed to all participants.
Participants
A total of 36 participants were recruited from the university population to participate in this study. Of the 36, 14 demonstrated IHI during arm cycling, while 10 demonstrated IHI during an intensity-matched tonic contraction. A total of 8 participants demonstrated IHI in both the cycling and tonic contraction conditions. A subset of these data has been published previously regarding the cycling information (Benson et al. 2021). However, due to the difficulty in eliciting IHI in both cycling and tonic tasks, we were unable appropriately compare tonic and cycling tasks in the Benson et al. (2020) study. As such, we collected data on additional participants for each group for the present work.
A total of eight male participants (height 177.6 ± 5.89 cm; weight 78.6 ± 8.84 kg; age 22.2 ± 2.3 years) with no known neurological disorders were used to compare IHI between tasks. All participants completed a safety checklist to screen for any possible risks to magnetic simulation (Rossini et al. 2015), and a Physical Activity Readiness Questionnaire to screen for any contraindications to physical activity (Canadian Society for Exercise Physiology, 2002). Hand dominance was determined using the Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Veale 2014). This was done to ensure that investigations of IHI were done with respect to the non-dominant arm, as interhemispheric inhibitory connections are strongest from the non-dominant to the dominant hemisphere (Netz et al. 1995; Chen et al. 2003; Bäumer et al. 2007). All participants were familiarized with the stimulations and arm cycling prior to data collection.
Study design
All arm cycling trials were performed using an arm cycle ergometer (SCIFIT ergometer, model PRO2 Total Body, Tulsa, OK, USA) with participants cycling with a neutral forearm position. The arm cranks were locked 180 º out of phase to establish an asynchronous cycling pattern (Fig. 1A). To ensure participant comfort, participants were seated in an upright position at a comfortable distance from the hand cranks to ensure that there was no flexion or rotation of the torso during cycling, and the seat height was adjusted, so that participants' shoulders were level with the axis of rotation of the arm cranks. Participants were asked to wear wrist braces to minimize the amount of wrist flexion and extension during cycling, as to limit the influence of heteronymous reflex connections that exist between the wrist flexors and the biceps brachii (Manning and Bawa 2011). TMS was delivered to the dominant motor cortex when the non-dominant arm passed the 6 o'clock position during mid-elbow flexion where the non-dominant biceps brachii are most active (Chaytor et al. 2020). Similar to previous arm cycling studies, 6 o'clock was specified as the "bottom dead centre" of the cycling pattern (Balter and Zehr 2007; Forman et al. 2014, 2015; Copithorne et al. 2015; Lockyer et al. 2018). All participants cycled at 60 revolutions per minute (RPM) and 25 watts for a total of 150 s, over which they received 30 TMS stimulations interspersed by 5 s.Fig. 1

To match the tonic and cycling trials, the average background EMG (bEMG) of the biceps brachii 50 ms before stimulation from the cycling trial was assessed. The average value of the rectified bEMG served as an indication of contraction intensity which has been done previously (Forman et al. 2014, 2015). Following the cycling task, the average of the rectified bEMG was then displayed on a computer screen via a horizontal line. The arm cranks were locked with the non-dominant arm at the 6 o'clock position, and participants were then required to produce a tonic contraction whereby the EMG produced in the biceps brachii was equal to the horizontal line displayed on the screen (Forman et al. 2014). The participant accomplished this by placing both hands on the arm cranks and pulling with the non-dominant arm (Fig. 1C). The participant was able to see the ongoing muscle activity of the non-dominant biceps brachii and was instructed to contract at an intensity in which the ongoing EMG matched the pre-placed horizontal line representing cycling bEMG. The dominant arm was placed at the 12 o'clock position, with the hand holding onto the handle as it would during arm cycling. This method of matching EMG activity between tasks has shown success in previous works (Pyndt et al. 2003; Carroll et al. 2006; Forman et al. 2014). TMS was delivered to the dominant motor cortex, while the non-dominant biceps brachii was producing a contraction of the same intensity observed during arm cycling; thus, any differences in IHI could theoretically be attributed to the task. The number of stimulations was the same as that during cycling (see Experimental Protocol).
Transcranial magnetic stimulation
TMS to the motor cortex was applied using a Magstim 200 stimulator (Magstim, Whitland, Dyfed, UK). During both experimental conditions, a figure-eight coil (external loop diameters of 9 cm) was placed 2 cm lateral to vertex with the handle pointing posterolaterally at 45 degrees to the midline of the head. To isolate the biceps brachii representation of the motor cortex, the stimulator was turned to a suprathreshold intensity (~ 75% maximal stimulator output, i.e., MSO) and moved around the head until the largest MEP could be evoked with the dominant arm biceps brachii at rest. This location was defined as the 'hot spot' and was marked with a marker. To ensure an accurate marking of the hot spot, all participants wore a white swim cap to allow the researchers to trace around the TMS coil. To find the resting motor threshold (RMT), participants were instructed to rest with both hands on the handles of the cycle ergometer with the dominant hand at the 6 o'clock position. RMT was found by decreasing the stimulation intensity to the minimum value in which an MEP of ~ 50 [mu]V in peak-to-peak amplitude could be evoked in the dominant biceps in 4 of 8 trials via stimulation of the hot spot (Rothwell et al. 1999). Stimulation intensity was then increased to 120% RMT, as this intensity has been shown to display a clear iSP without evoking a short-latency facilitation (Perez et al. 2014) and was successfully used during arm cycling in our prior work (Benson et al. 2021). TMS stimulation intensity remained constant for the remainder of the experimental protocol using an anterior-posterior directed current.
Electromyography
EMG recordings were taken from the biceps brachii of both arms using pairs of Ag-AgCl surface electrodes (KendallTM 130 Foam Electrodes with conductive adhesive hydrogel, Covidien IIC, Massachusetts, USA). Electrodes were placed 2 cm apart (centre to centre) over the midline of the muscle belly, in a parallel fashion with respect to the target muscle fibres. A ground electrode was placed on the lateral epicondyle of the right limb. Prior to electrode placement, the skin was thoroughly prepared by removal of dead epithelial cells (using abrasive paper) followed by sanitization with an isopropyl alcohol swab. EMG was collected on-line and analog-to-digitally converted at a rate of 5 kHz using CED 1401 interface and the associated Signal 5 (Cambridge Electronic Design Ltd., Cambridge, UK) software. All signals were amplified (x 300) and filtered using a 3-Pole Butterworth filter with cut-off frequencies of 10-1000 Hz. Collected data were stored on a password protected PC for further analysis.
Experimental protocol
Following the determination of required TMS intensity, participants completed 2 trials (1 arm cycling and 1 tonic contraction trial). During arm cycling, TMS was delivered to the dominant motor cortex when the non-dominant arm passed the 6 o'clock position, as to elicit an iSP in the non-dominant biceps brachii during mid-elbow flexion. During tonic contraction, TMS was delivered to the dominant motor cortex, while the non-dominant biceps brachii produced a tonic contraction of matched intensity to that of arm cycling. Since tonic contraction intensity was matched to the EMG observed during the arm cycling conditions, it was necessary to perform the arm cycling condition first (Lockyer et al. 2021). During both conditions, participants received a total of 30 TMS pulses. In the scenario where an ipsilateral MEP was evident, the trial was removed, and the remaining trials were analyzed.
Data analysis
Ipsilateral silent period
During arm cycling trials, the iSP was measured in the biceps brachii of the non-dominant arm during elbow flexion when the biceps brachii is active (Forman et al. 2014, 2015; Spence et al. 2016; Lockyer et al. 2018). To obtain the average iSP, all 30 EMG traces from the cycling trials were averaged and a single iSP measurement taken and was used to compare between tasks. Stimulations were triggered at the 6 o'clock position of arm cycling (mid-elbow flexion or bottom dead centre). An average iSP was measured from 30 cycling trials. Given the differences between the tonic and cycling protocols, different methods to assess iSP were necessary for each condition. For tonic trials, the onset of the iSP was determined offline via visual examination of the EMG trace following the stimulus artifact and was defined as the time point when the rectified EMG fell below the bEMG for a minimum of 10 ms. The bEMG was defined as the mean of the rectified EMG channel over a 50 ms window immediately prior to the stimulation artifact. The end of the iSP occurred when the rectified EMG returned to the bEMG average. The duration of the iSP was the time-interval between the onset and end of the iSP. For cycling trials, because muscle activity follows a sinusoidal type of pattern of activation and inactivation (Chaytor et al. 2020), an alternative measure was required. As such, iSP was determined offline via visual examination of the EMG trace following the stimulus artifact and was defined as the time point when the rectified EMG fell below the bEMG for a minimum of 10 ms. However, for appropriate assessment of IHI, the control iSP EMG was time- and position-matched and taken from the subsequent cycling revolution where no stimulation occurred (i.e., control EMG, see Fig. 1B). Control EMG was calculated 1 s after the iSP and for the same duration as the iSP (i.e., in the subsequent EMG burst during arm cycling). This ensured that control EMG was calculated during the same cycling phase and for the same duration as the iSP, given a 60 RPM cadence.
The depth of the iSP was calculated from the average rectified EMG during the entirety of the iSP and expressed as the percentage of reduction from the average bEMG or control EMG [iSP depth = 100 - (mean rectified iSP EMG/mean rectified bEMG or control EMG) * 100]. Finally, the area of the iSP was calculated using the following formula [tonic: iSP area = (mean rectified pre-stimulus EMG) * (iSP duration) - (au_iSP); cycling: iSP area = (au_control EMG - au_iSP)], where au_iSP is the area under the rectified EMG during the iSP and au_control EMG is area under the rectified EMG during the control EMG (Perez et al. 2014). Finally, assessments in EMG were completed following the iSP. A 50 ms duration of the rectified EMG following the iSP and control EMG were assessed and compared within and between tasks to better understand what is occurring following the inhibition. Any trials in which short-latency facilitation was observed were removed from data analysis, as this could mask any potential inhibitory effects (Perez et al. 2014).
Statistical analysis
All statistics were performed in SPSS (SPSS 20 for Macintosh, IBM Corporation, Armonk, New York, USA). All data were normally distributed (p > 0.05; Shapiro-Wilk tests). Assumptions of sphericity were tested using Mauchley's test. If violated, the degrees of freedom were corrected using Greenhouse-Geisser estimates of sphericity. Paired-samples two-tailed t tests were used to assess any differences in bEMG, iSP depth, iSP duration, iSP onset, and iSP area. All data are presented as mean ± standard deviation and the alpha level was set at p < 0.05.
Methodological considerations
Several methodological considerations must be taken into account in the interpretation of the present results (Lockyer et al. 2021). First, it is unlikely, but possible, that subcortical pathways contributed to the observed task-dependent difference in IHI given that we did not assess spinal excitability. However, others have previously reported no spinal contribution (Perez et al. 2014). Second, the time delay between the conditioning of the motor cortex with a TMS pulse means that although the motor cortex would have been conditioned at mid-elbow flexion, corresponding with our prior work, the iSP measurements were examined during the inactivation phase of the biceps brachii as the EMG levels return to baseline (Fig. 1). Previous work showed that SICI to the knee extensors was absent during tonic contractions and the activation phase of leg cycling but present during the inactivation phase. Thus, potential phase-dependent differences in IHI within the cycling task may be at play with IHI stronger during the inactivation phase of the biceps brachii. Regardless, the presence of IHI during the inactivation phase allowed a comparison to a tonic contraction. Third, it was also necessary to obtain a control EMG value for the cycling condition from a subsequent burst of EMG. This may have resulted in slightly different EMG values given the inherent variability of the EMG burst during dynamic motor output. We are confident, however, that the timing of the EMG burst, and the phase of the cycle was likely not different based on prior work (Lockyer et al. 2019). We have previously shown that participants required to cycle at a set cadence were within 1.5 RPM of said cadence (Lockyer et al. 2019). This 1.5 RPM difference represents only ~ 4 ms per revolution, indicating that differences in cadence, though not recorded, were unlikely to affect the phase-dependent measures of IHI. Note that at a cadence of 60 RPM, the time difference between each phase as determined by the hour position on a clock represents 83.3 ms.
In addition to these considerations, it is worth noting that difficulties eliciting IHI have been previously reported (Perez et al. 2014), where only 50% of the subjects demonstrated IHI. The reason for this technical difficulty is currently unknown. This percentage is further reduced when attempting to assess IHI in different muscles (Perez et al. 2014) or in different tasks, as evident in this current study. Fourth, though a task-dependent difference in bEMG was observed, the finding was not significant and may be due to a type II error given the low sample size. This is important to consider given that bEMG may influence the silent period. Finally, we did not record EMG from the antagonist muscle group, thus limiting our ability to comment on co-contraction and possible neural implications nor did we use a neuronavigation system.

Results
A total of 36 participants were tested; however, we were unable to identify a clear iSP in either condition for 20 participants. Thus, these data were excluded from the analyses. Of the remaining 16 participants, 14 participants exhibited a clear iSP during arm cycling, while 10 participants exhibited discernable iSPs during tonic contractions.
Arm cycling and tonic contraction trials
In the arm cycling trials (n = 14), the averaged MSOs used to elicit RMT and the iSP were 54.6 ± 8.74% and 65.6 ± 10.5%, respectively. In the tonic contraction trials (n = 10), the averaged MSOs used to elicit RMT and the iSP were 52.9 ± 9.16% and 63.5 ± 11.0%, respectively.
In total, eight participants demonstrated clearly discernable iSPs during both tasks. Data for these participants were compared. Figure 1 shows an example of the iSPs in the non-dominant biceps brachii from one participant who showed an iSP during both arm cycling (B ) and tonic contraction (D ).
Arm cycling vs. tonic contraction
Eight of the participants tested in the study displayed a visible iSP in both arm cycling and tonic contraction. Importantly, to accurately compare iSPs between the two tasks, matching for muscle activity prior to stimulation was necessary (Lockyer et al. 2021). This was achieved as there were no significant differences between the two tasks for bEMG when taken at the 6 o'clock position (142 ± 47.0 [micro]V and 123 ± 44.0 [micro]V for arm cycling and tonic contraction, respectively, p = 0.12) (see Fig. 2A). However, there were notable differences in IHI parameters between the two tasks. Specifically, iSP duration was longer during arm cycling compared to tonic contraction (49.1 ± 14.2 ms vs 33.6 ± 10.7 ms, respectively, p < 0.05; Cohen's D = 1.3; see Fig. 2B).Fig. 2

There were no significant differences between iSP EMG (104 ± 41.0 [micro]V and 95 ± 36.0 [micro]V for arm cycling and tonic contraction, respectively, p = 0.46; see Fig. 2C), onset (30.9 ± 3.86 ms and 33.7 ± 15.0 ms for arm cycling and tonic contraction, respectively; p = 0.58), depth (20.9 ± 14.3% and 23.2 ± 3.09% for arm cycling and tonic contraction, respectively, p = 0.71), or area (cycling: 1400 ± 1440 [micro]V*ms; tonic: 828 ± 217 [micro]V*ms, p = 0.32) of the iSP between the two conditions.
Interestingly, there was an unexpected compensatory rebound EMG burst following the iSP (i.e., post-inhibitory rebound) during arm cycling that was not present during the tonic contraction trials. We then compared the EMG using a 50 ms post-iSP window to the position-matched 50 ms post-control EMG. The EMG burst post-iSP was significantly larger (156 ± 81 [micro]V vs 113 ± 58.0 [micro]V, p < 0.05; Cohen's D = 0.6). While EMG 50 ms post-iSP in the tonic condition does increase following iSP, it is not significantly different from the bEMG (133 ± 45.0 [micro]V vs 123 ± 44.0 [micro]V, respectively) (Table 1). When comparing the differences in the compensatory rebound EMG to a control measure (i.e., background EMG for tonic and control burst for cycling), there is a significant difference between cycling and tonic tasks (cycling difference: 43 ± 38.0 [micro]V; tonic difference: 10 ± 19.0 [micro]V, p < 0.01; see Fig. 1B and D).
